title: String Matching Query
problem_statement:
String Matching Query

Write a function that takes a string and a vector of queries to find matching substrings. For each query in the vector, determine if there is a matching substring and return the results.

Input Format

  • A string s containing lowercase letters
  • A vector of integers queries where each query contains two integers representing substring indices

Output Format

Return a vector of integers representing the results for each query.

Function Signature

vector<int> solve(string s, vector<int> queries)

Examples

Input:
String s = \"abceabcf\"
Queries = [8, 1, 3, 2, 5, 3, 3, 4, 4]
Output:
[3, 2, 1, 0]

In the second test case, the substring [2,5] = \"bce\". Its prefix matches best with substring starting from index 6. Hence, the answer is 2.

Code Template

#include<bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;

vector<int> solve(string s, vector<int> queries) {
    // Write your code here
}

int main() {
    ios::sync_with_stdio(0);
    cin.tie(0);
    string s;
    // Rest of the main function
}

title: Can King Be Saved?
problem_statement:
Can King Be Saved?

Given an N×N chessboard, with K queens and one king on it. You may move the king at most once. You cannot capture any piece with the king. You need to tell whether you can move the king to a square such that it is safe from all the queens that will attack the king after this move. This means that no queen should capture the king after the move of the king.

Formally, if the initial position of the king is (x1, y1) and the position of the king after 1 move is (x2, y2), then |x1-x2| ≤ 1 and |y1-y2| ≤ 1 where |a| denotes modulus of a.

Note: You may also decide not to move the king. And if you decide to move the king, you should ensure that it does not go out of the board.

Note: You cannot capture any piece with the king.

Reminder: The king can move to any cell that is adjacent to the current cell, in all eight directions.

Input Format

  • The first line contains integer \'N\' (side length of the chessboard)
  • The rows are numbered from \'1\' to \'N\' from top to bottom and columns are numbered from \'1\' to \'N\' from left to right
  • We denote a cell on the intersection of i-th row and j-th column as \'(i,j)\'
  • The next line contains \"king_x\", denoting the x co-ordinate of the king
  • The next line contains \"king_y\", denoting the y co-ordinate of the king
  • The next line contains K, denoting the number of queens on the board
  • The next \'K\' lines contain two integers \'[i]\' and \'c[i]\' (coordinates of the i-th queen)

Output Format

If it is possible to save the king, print in a single line \"Yes\" (without quotes) else print \"No\" (without quotes).

Constraints

  • 2 ≤ N ≤ 1,000,000,000,000,000,000
  • 1 ≤ K ≤ 1,000,000
  • 1 ≤ R,C[i][j] ≤ N

Examples

Input:
3
2
2
1
1 1
Output:
Yes

The king is at (2, 2) and the queen is at (1, 1). Initially, the king is in threat. If the king does not move, he will be attacked by the queen as (2, 2) is reachable from (1, 1) for the queen in one move.

Now, the king should make a move. Ideally, the king would have 8 possible choices to move as there are 8 neighbouring cells of the king within the chessboard but he cannot move to (1, 1) as it is already occupied by the queen.

He is left with only 7 choices.

Function Signature

def canKingbeSaved(n, king_x, king_y, queen):
    # Write your code here

title: Safe King on Chessboard
problem_statement:
Safe King on Chessboard

Given an N×N chessboard, with K queens and one king on it. You may move the king at most once. You cannot capture any piece with the king. You need to tell whether you can move the king on such a square, such that it is safe from all the queens, that will attack the king after this move. This means that no queen should capture the king after the move of the king.

Formally, if the initial position of the king is (x1, y1) and the position of the king after 1 move is (x2, y2), then |x1 - x2| ≤ 1 and |y1 - y2| ≤ 1, where |a| denotes modulus of a.

Note: You may also decide not to move the king. And if you decide to move the king, you should ensure that it does not go out of the board.

Note: You cannot capture any piece with the king.

Reminder – The king can move at any cell, that is adjacent to the current cell, in all eight directions.

Input Format

The first line contains integers \'N\' (side length of the chessboard).
The rows are numbered from \'1\' to \'N\' from top to bottom and columns are numbered from \'1\' to \'N\' from left to right.
We denote a cell on the intersection of the r-th row and c-th column as \'(r,c)\'.
The next line contains \"king_x\", denoting the x coordinate of the king.
The next line contains \"king_y\", denoting the y coordinate of the king.
The next line contains K, denoting the number of queens on the board.
The next \'K\' lines contain two integers \'[ri]\' and \'[ci]\' (coordinates of the i-th queen).

Output Format

If it is possible to save the king, print in a single line \"Yes\" (without quotes) else print \"No\" (without quotes).

Constraints

  • 2 ≤ N ≤ 1,000,000,000,000,000,000
  • 1 ≤ K ≤ 1,000,000
  • 1 ≤ Ri, Ci ≤ N

Examples

Input:
3
2
2
1
1 1
Output:
Yes

The king is at (2, 2) and the queen is at (1, 1). Initially, the king is in threat. If the king does not move, he will be attacked by the queen as (2, 2) is reachable from (1, 1) for the queen in one move.

Now, the king should make a move. Ideally, the king would have 8 possible choices to move as there are 8 neighboring cells of the king within the chessboard but he cannot move to (1, 1) as it is already occupied by the queen.

He is left with only 7 choices. He should not move to either of (1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 1), (3, 1), (3, 2), (3, 3) as all of these cells are reachable for the queen. So, in order to be safe, he can either move to (2, 3) or (3, 2). Both of these positions are safe as the queen is not present in either of the positions and also the queen will not be able to reach these positions by making only one move. So, the output is \"Yes\".
